awd_titl_txt: Explorations in Particle Theory and Cosmology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Kaustubh Agashe, Zackaria Chacko, Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Raman Sundrum at the University of Maryland, College Park. Their work will develop new theoretical mechanisms and models at the juncture of Relativity and Quantum Mechanics, and result in new templates for experimental exploration in diverse arenas. The experimental frontier ranges from searches for new particles at the CERN Large Hadron Collider and future colliders, to Dark Matter detection experiments, to particle physics signatures in the Cosmic Microwave Background and Large Scale Structure in the universe, to searches for gravitational waves from early universe phase transitions. This research seeks to improve our understanding of the fundamental laws of nature, lying at the root of the natural sciences, and thereby to benefit the national interest and our scientific civilization. In their research, the principal investigators will study several of the most promising theoretical frameworks for going beyond the standard model of particle physics, in which it is augmented by (a) extra 'warped' dimensions of spacetime, (b) 'mirror sectors' with similar structure to the standard model and mirror symmetries that relate them, (c) 'left-right' symmetric structure. They will also study the physics and cosmology of neutrinos, as well as models of "cosmic inflation", the growth spurt of the early universe. This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts.  The PIs will involve graduate students and postdocs in their research, and thereby provide critical training for junior physicists beginning research in this field.  They also intend to give public and high school lectures on their research results and aid in the development of materials for the scientific media. 

More technically, Professors Agashe and Sundrum will explore the physics of the warped extra-dimensional phase transition in the early universe, and its gravitational wave and collider phenomenology, as well as its role in generating the observed matter/antimatter asymmetry. Professor Sundrum will also develop theories of high-scale cosmic inflation compatible with the most recent precision cosmological data. The left-right symmetric scenario will be studied by Professor Mohapatra for its possible impact on flavor physics, neutrino physics and the matter/antimatter asymmetry. The physics of neutrinos will be studied by Professor Chacko in scenarios in which they are associated with compositeness, time-dependent couplings, or couplings to light Goldstone bosons.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award was made to four principal investigators, Kaustubh Agashe, Zackaria Chacko, Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Raman Sundrum. The goals of this project were to conduct theoretical investigations to expand our knowledge of the fundamental forces and microscopic constituents of nature, and to combine this with the cosmic expansion of spacetime to understand the evolution of the Universe as a whole. A broad range of topics were studied, such as supersymmetry, extra space dimensions, neutrino physics, grand unification of matter and forces, the cosmic origin of matter, the inflationary "growth spurt" of the early universe, and the mystery of Dark Matter. The unifying theme was the search for new physics ideas testable at the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and various ongoing non-accelerator experiments, as well as in cosmological measurements of the "fossils" of the Big Bang. The results research significantly helps extend the frontiers of understanding of fundamental laws, the early Universe, and the prospects for a diverse range of upcoming experiments.

Major outcomes.  Neutrinos are among the most elusive and enigmatic particle known, and potentially a prime "portal" to physics beyond the standard model. The research project developed new theories, and harnessed precision cosmological measurements to provide new experimental tests of the origin of neutrino masses, the possibility that they are composite objects, and the possibilty that they have a finite lifetime at odds with standard model theory. The fact that most of the mass in our Universe is not made of conventional atoms, poses a central scientific puzzle as to the constitutents of this Dark Matter. One attractive possibility that was studied in the project is that the dark matter lives within a "mirror" sector of particle physics. The possibilities and constraints for ordinary neutrons converting into "mirror neutrons" was studied, ranging from terrestrial experiments to cosmological signals to neutron star phenomenology. PIs also studied one of the dominant overarching paradigms for new particle physics, Supersymmetry, which relates matter-like particles ("fermions") to force-carrier particles ("bosons"), building specific models that are consistent with all experimental constraints while predicting new particles that can be discovered at the ongoing LHC experiments, dark matter detection experiments, and measurement of the muon particle's "magnetic moment" where there is currently an intriguing discrepancy with standard particle theory. There is a remarkable potential for statistical correlations within the cosmic microwave background (CMB), galaxy distributions and cosmological gravitational waves to contain "fossilized" records of the laws of nature as they existed in the earliest period of our Universe, "cosmic Inflation". Research in this project uncovered new mechanisms and strategies for increasing the theoretical scope of this program, as well as broadening the experimental toolkit, such as by harnessing proposed precision gravitational wave detectors.

Broader impact and outreach. The field of particle physics and cosmology provides an excellent training ground and inspiration for science in general. The PIs have given talks and interacted with interested high school students, as well conducting physics demonstrations for the general public during Maryland Day (the open house of the university). They have also had repeated success in developing young scientists, graduate students and postdocs, for successful careers, in physics faculty positions as well as out of academia where their theoretical modeling skills are in high demand in the workforce.
